metadata.sermon_start_end: Was mich am meisten an der gegenwärtigen Leitung der römischen Kirche empört, ist die Art, in der sie mit denen umgeht, die die christliche Botschaft am glaubwürdigsten leben. Was mich empört, ist der Verrat an den Armen und allen, die auf ihrer Seite sind [...] Ich werde meinen Odem in euch legen, dass ihr wieder lebendig werdet (Ezechiel 37,12 f.).

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The text does not focus on one specific passage. It uses Ezekiel 33:11 as a rhetorical hook and jumps to 1 Thessalonians, Matthew, and Ezekiel 37. It is a thematic speech about church politics rather than an exposition of a specific pericope.
quotes: Warum wollt ihr denn sterben? Ich würde die Frage des Propheten Ezechiel an das Volk Israel heute so übersetzen...
Löscht den Geist nicht aus beschwört Paulus die Gemeinde in Thessaloniki (1 Thessalonicher 5,19).
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one pericope (e.g., Ezekiel 37:1-14) and derive the entire movement from its specific imagery rather than using verses as slogans for a pre-determined political critique.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no historical-critical or linguistic exegesis. The original context of Ezekiel’s exile or the Thessalonian situation is ignored. The preacher immediately 'translates' the text into contemporary polemics.
quotes: Ich würde die Frage des Propheten Ezechiel an das Volk Israel heute so übersetzen: Warum wollt ihr die Zahl der Mitarbeiterinnen Gottes künstlich... vermindern
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Engage with the Hebrew/Greek context. What did 'death' and 'spirit' mean for Ezekiel's audience? Avoid immediate allegorization into 20th-century church structures.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is very concrete and contemporary, showing a broad knowledge of sociology and church politics. However, it borders on a political lecture rather than a biblical application.
quotes: der nicaraguanische Obanda y Bravo. Ich erwähne diesen Fall... um die Menschenverachtung offenzulegen
das Kreuz von Wackersdorf ist Symbol der heute am Kreuz hängenden Erde
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ground the concrete application in the text's logic rather than using the text as a springboard for a critique of the Vatican.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: Exposition is almost entirely absent, so there is no real 'interweaving.' The text is used as a motto for the application. The hearer is drawn into a political conflict, not into the biblical text.
quotes: Warum wollt ihr denn sterben? Warum gebt ihr den Leuten kein Brot zu essen, sondern füttert sie mit Pappe und Klischees...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Allow the biblical text to 'expound' the hearer. The movement should go from the text to the world, not from the world to a proof-text.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery is present but defined sociologically/institutionally (sexism, lack of democracy). Redemption is seen in the 'Liberation Theology' movement. The focus is heavily on human action and institutional failure.
quotes: Das gegenwärtige römische System verachtet die Frauen...
Die Theologie der Befreiung hat die spirituelle Tiefe... die zu einer neuen Reformation führen könnte.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the concept of misery beyond institutional critique to the 'misery before God.' Ensure redemption is seen as God's act (grace) rather than a specific theological school.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are present as a choice between institutional death and spiritual life. The seriousness is high, but the 'lostness' is purely temporal/historical.
quotes: Warum lasst ihr die Kirche lieber kaputtgehen als sie im Sinne der urchristlichen Gemeinschaft der Gleichen zu erneuern?
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the ultimate possibility of being lost in eternity, not just the historical decline of an institution.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as a 'telos' of sorts, but primarily as a model for the 'community of equals' or the 'perspective of the powerless.' The doctrine of the two natures is not operative.
quotes: Dass sie von Gott spricht aus der Perspektive Gottes, die die der Machtlosen ist, der Armen, der Frauen, der Anderen.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Make Christ the goal of the sermon as the source of salvation outside of human political success. Focus on grace as the 'deepest of our life' rather than political reform.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 11 minutes (1150 words), the sermon is too short according to Dekker's 20-minute rule. It lacks the 'breadth' required for theological depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the sermon to at least 20 minutes by incorporating rigorous biblical exposition and a broader dogmatic framework.

overall_assessment.summary: The text fails Dekker's primary formal definition of a sermon. It is a polemical speech (Philippic) against the Roman Catholic hierarchy rather than an exposition and application of a specific Bible passage. It lacks linguistic exegesis and treats biblical verses as rhetorical ornaments for a pre-existing socio-political agenda.
strengths: High degree of concreteness in contemporary application
Serious engagement with the 'zeitgeist' and institutional crisis
Clear call to responsibility (the 'two ways' of institutional life/death)
weaknesses: Lack of a single, specific biblical pericope as the foundation
Absence of original language exegesis and historical context
Duration is significantly below the 20-minute threshold for 'depth'
Redemption is identified with a human movement (Liberation Theology) rather than the objective work of Christ
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the sense of Dekker’s definition. It is a thematic address on church politics. By neglecting the specific, unique word of a single Bible passage, it offers 'general truths' (or general critiques) that could be found elsewhere, failing the fundamental test of homiletic specificity.
